description: Coined early 1843 (January or February) by Spencer Timothy Hall. From Latin aqua (“water”) + -ative (“related to”)  +‎ -ness (“the quality of”).

entries.meaning: (phrenology, obsolete, obscure) love of liquids, including drinking, bathing, and sailing.
examples: Just in front of Alimentiveness, is one or more organs which create a love of drinking, bathing, sailing, &c., which might be called Aquativeness, or Bibativeness, or Thirst, as thought best.
